title: Is 'man flu' real?
intro: A recently published study may have the answer. Can science prove that men really do suffer more, or do they just moan instead of getting on with it? Dan and Neil teach six items of vocabulary and discuss the issue.
this_week_question: In a survey conducted by Nuts magazine that asked its readers how long they took to recover from a cold or flu, where women put an average of 1.5 days, what did men put? a) 1 day b) 2 days c) 3 days
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: when a person's nose leaks mucus
the situation where a person, often a man, tends to complain and exaggerate a small illness such as a cold
complaining repeatedly often in an annoying way symptoms feelings of illness caused by a disease

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Dan, and joining me today is Neil. Hi Neil.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hi, everyone!

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Bless you! Are you ok?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I think I’m coming down with something serious.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: It’s just a case of the sniffles . Neil The sniffles is an informal way of saying a cold or flu. It comes from the sniffing sound people make when they have a runny nose .

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: And a runny nose is when liquid mucus keeps leaking from our nose – usually when we are sick. I’m afraid you’ll just have to soldier on Neil.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: To soldier on means to continue despite difficulty. I’m dying! What’s it about anyway?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: It’s about ‘man flu’, and whether it’s actually real, or just something men like to complain about. We'll give you 6 words and expressions – and, of course, our quiz question.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Alright, fire away.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Dan In a survey conducted by Nuts magazine that asked its readers how long they took to recover from a cold or flu, where women put an average of 1.5 days, what did men put?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I’m going to say 3 days. The threat of ‘man flu’ is real.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Well, we’ll find out later, but let’s clarify. ‘ Man flu’ is the tendency that many people believe men have to complain about a minor illness, such as a cold or flu, and act as if they were suffering from something a lot more serious.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes. But science cannot say whether men do actually suffer more than women, or if men just tend to complain more.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Well, let’s hear from this British couple about whether they think ‘man flu’ is real or not.

transcript.author: Vox
transcript.text: British Man Men definitely do suffer a lot more, I think, than women do when we get flu.

transcript.author: British Woman
transcript.text: Yeah, I’m not so convinced. I feel like they just complain more.

transcript.author: British Man
transcript.text: It wipes me out. British Woman I was ill recently and I just carried on and went to work and everything. And when Chris had got sick recently he was on the sofa and couldn’t really do anything, so…

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: And it seems that it’s not just in the UK. Listen to this BBC Journalist interviewing a woman from Europe.

transcript.author: Vox
transcript.text: BBC Journalist You’re from the Netherlands. Have you ever accused your boyfriend of having man flu?

transcript.author: Dutch woman
transcript.text: Oh, absolutely yes. Yeah.

transcript.author: BBC Journalist
transcript.text: What have you accused him of doing?

transcript.author: Dutch woman
transcript.text: … whining ?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Whining is when someone complains repeatedly and often in an annoying way about something. So, there certainly seems to be something there…but nothing has been proven, right?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Well, a recent scientific study has indicated that there could be something to ‘man flu’ after all. Doctor Kyle Sue, an assistant professor of family medicine at Memorial University of Newfoundland in Canada, has suggested that there could be a difference between men and women when it comes to respiratory diseases.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Respiratory meaning related to breathing. He says that there was already a lot of evidence from existing studies suggesting men experience worse, longer-lasting symptoms .

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Symptoms are the feelings of illness caused by a disease. Listen to him explain why this is.

transcript.author: Doctor Kyle Sue
transcript.text: , Memorial University, Newfoundland It seems that the higher the testosterone levels, the lower the immune response to these types of infections, whereas the higher the oestrogen level, the stronger the immune response.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Testosterone and oestrogen are hormones that exist in both men and women. Testosterone is higher in males and oestrogen is higher in females. Dr. Sue’s research suggests that the more oestrogen a person has, the better able they are to fight off the infection. That’s it then! Man flu is real! Dan Hold your horses, Neil. There are two problems. First of all, the Royal college of GPs in the UK says that there is no such thing as ‘man flu’. And secondly, even Dr Sue admits that these results, including his own, are only ‘suggestive’ and are not ‘definitive’.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So, basically he’s saying that there is a suggestion that ‘man flu’ exists, but the evidence so far cannot say for sure.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Exactly. More studies need to be done. But you know what we can be sure about? The answer to this week’s quiz question. I asked you in a survey conducted by Nuts magazine that asked its readers how long they took to recover from a cold or flu, where women put an average of 1.5 days, what did men put?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I said 3 days.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: And you were right!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Good! Dan The men said they took twice as long to recover! Neil It must be all that manly testosterone. Let’s review our vocabulary, shall we?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Our first was the sniffles . If you have the sniffles, you have a cold, informally speaking. What's the best cure for the sniffles Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Stay in bed and sweat it out, my mum always said. Just make sure you have lots of tissues to deal with your runny nose . That’s when a person’s nose leaks mucus, usually because they are ill. Yuck!

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Next we had soldier on . This phrasal verb means to continue despite difficulty. When was the last time you had to soldier on , Neil? Neil A few days ago when I went the whole day without eating any lunch! Then we had ‘ man flu’. That’s is the name given to the situation where a person, often a man, tends to complain and exaggerate a small illness such as a cold. Do you do that, Dan? Dan I’m sure my wife would say I do! Next we had whining . If you whine , you complain repeatedly and often in an annoying way. Neil Like my children did last time I didn’t buy them ice-cream. And finally we had symptoms . These are the feelings of illness caused by a disease. What are the symptoms of flu, Dan? Dan A headache, aching muscles, and a fever. And that’s the end of this 6 Minute English! Don’t forget to check out our YouTube, Facebook, Twitter and Instagram pages. There you made it. You can collapse now. Neil Bye. Dan Bye!
